column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Conclusions
#Text=In this paper , we propose the application of a relatively new and robust RNN to forecast hourly solar irradiance .

#Text=We applied univariate and multivariate GRU models using historical solar irradiance , exogenous meteorological variables , and cloud cover data to forecast solar irradiance in Phoenix , Arizona .
#Text=The proposed is compared with LSTM , another popular deep learning model .

#Text=We further analyze the performance of models to forecast multiple time steps into future , how the models perform with cloud cover variable , and how the performance of different models vary across a given day , over the year , and days with high variability in irradiance .
#Text=Our primary motivation for this work is to be able to find a model that can continuously produce real-time forecasts based on publicly available weather data .
#Text=Therefore , we also study the computational performance of various models .
#Text=Overall , multivariate deep learning methods perform better than univariate models .
#Text=There is significant performance improvement with including cloud cover in the multivariate models .

#Text=We observe from Phoenix dataset that multivariate LSTM has slightly less error compared to multivariate GRU , but multivariate GRU has less training and prediction time compared to multivariate LSTM .
#Text=There is not much difference between per month MAPE and RMSE between multivariate GRU and multivariate LSTM .
#Text=In our future work , we would like to improve irradiance forecasting performance that would further help grid operators to manage uncertainty associated with solar power .

#Text=This includes using better quality cloud cover data in the model , techniques to further improve the performance of the model , and finally , evaluating the utility of these models to help grid operators manage the variability of irradiance under different conditions .
#Text=The proposed deep learning methods could be further improved by incorporating more detailed cloud cover related features as well as higher resolution GHI data .

#Text=The data used in our experiments includes hourly GHI data which is freely available from NREL , but many solar installations collect one-minute resolution data that could be used to potentially improve the model performance .
#Text=On days where there is no cloud cover , both models performed exceptionally ; however , on days with cloud cover , both models fail to accurately predict future solar irradiance .

#Text=Rather than having one static model to predict non-cloudy and cloudy days , we could potentially use ensemble methods or concept drift methods to reduce over-fitting on days where there is high variability in cloud cover .
#Text=Moreover , more research is needed in not only reducing the forecast error , but also maximizing the utility of irradiance forecasts .
#Text=The use of variables , namely back-of-module temperature and DNI , could be used to predict solar power plant production .

#Text=Being able to predict solar power plant production using DNI and back-of-module temperature would allow power grid operators to calculate future production directly , further reducing the margin of error .
